dt: {bc}to give or supply (something, such as money or time) as a part or share

dt.t: {wi}contributed{/wi} canned goods to the food drive
What percentage of your pay should you {wi}contribute{/wi} to your {d_link|401(k)|401(k)}?
We'd like to thank all who {wi}contributed{/wi} their time and effort.
I'm happy to attend, but I don't have much to {wi}contribute{/wi} to the discussion.
Many people {wi}contributed{/wi} to the fund-raising campaign.
If you are a parent, success is probably defined by how well your children turned out. Are they happy, successful adults? Do they {phrase}contribute to society{/phrase} in a positive way?

dt: {bc}to supply (something, such as an article) for a publication

dt.t: He {wi}contributed{/wi} several poems to the magazine.
The following authors {wi}contributed{/wi} to this issue: …

dt: {bc}to play a significant part in making something happen

dt.t: Many players have {wi}contributed{/wi} to the team's success.
{ldquo}We cannot address climate change without looking at all the components that are {wi}contributing{/wi} to the problem of emissions.{rdquo}

et: Latin {it}contributus{/it}, past participle of {it}contribuere{/it}, from {it}com-{/it} + {it}tribuere{/it} to grant {ma}{mat|tribute|}{/ma}
shortdef: to give or supply (something, such as money or time) as a part or share
to supply (something, such as an article) for a publication
to play a significant part in making something happen

dt.t: According to the police report of the accident, excessive speed was a {it}contributing factor{/it}.
The coach's positive attitude was a {it}contributing factor{/it} to/in the team's success.

shortdef: something that helps cause a result —often + to/in
